slidelink.displaytext: VIDEO: Welcome Video from the SilvaCarbon Program
VIDEO: Welcome Video from the SilvaCarbon Program
The challenges in monitoring forest degradation
Technical Challenges for Mapping and Monitoring Forest Degradation
How to create a change map using CODED.

search.slidetext: continuous degradation detection (coded) of forests in tropical countries made by the us government silvacarbon program, featuring dr. eric bullock from boston university start start start start start start click start to begin the program. version 1.5 copyright © 2020

introduction this e-learning course will introduce you to the idea of continuous degradation detection, or coded, and how it can be used to monitor and forecast forest health. by the end of this course you will learn about: the challenges of forest degradation monitoring the methodology and purpose of the continuous degradation detection (coded) algorithm spectral un-mixing and the normalized difference fraction index (ndfi) how degradation and natural disturbances are distinguished from deforestation use the and buttons to navigate between the screens of this e-learning program. you can view a list of all the screens by clicking the button, and a transcript of the audio narration for each screen is available by clicking the button. you can also adjust the volume, pause, and resume the screens and use the seek bar to move forward or back in a specific screen. using this e-learning program proceed now to the next screen by clicking the next button.

welcome video juliann aukema, senior program manager, usaid continuous degradation detection (coded) of forest in tropical countrieswelcome videojuliann aukema, senior program manager, usaid video duration: 1’ 18”

welcome video dr. eric bullock from boston university continuous degradation detection (coded) of forest in tropical countrieswelcome videodr. eric bullock from boston university dr. eric bullock received phd in geography from boston university developed the remote sensing methodology for monitoring forest degradation accurate monitoring of forest degradation over large areas is challenging introduction to key background topics related to forest degradation key technical challenges demonstrate how maps and area estimates can be obtained using the continuous degradation detection methodology video duration: 41”

earth engine 101 - javascript, images, collections, map and reduce x earth engine overview x necessary knowledge this course requires a basic understanding of the use of the google earth engine platform. you can register and open an account on google earth engine using the following link: to learn about the resources, and coding languages before starting this e-learning, check out the following tutorials: google earth engine earth engine overview earth engine 101 - javascript, images, collections, map and reduce the videos are from noel gorelick.

necessary knowledge e-learning tutorial on area and accuracy estimation: the following is an important tutorial on coded. using this tutorial you will have access to background documentation, code, and examples. e-learning tutorial on area and accuracy estimation tutorial on coded

the importance of monitoring forest degradation in the context of redd + reducing deforestation reducing degradation conservation sustainable managementof forest increasing c stocks deforestation is an activity that converts forest land to other land uses. for example, forest land converted to cropland or settlements. degradation, conservation of forest carbon stocks, and sustainable management of forests are activities that occur within forest land that is not converted to any other land covers. enhancement of forest carbon stocks can occur either within forest land that remains as forest land or by converting other land uses to forest land. both deforestation and forest degradation are activities that result in forest carbon loss. examples of activities that cause forest degradation include selective logging, non-natural forest fires, and fuelwood collection for household use. while deforestation has been the subject of intense debate on a global scale, forest degradation contributes significantly to greenhouse gas emissions and reduces the ability of forests to provide essential products and services and mitigate climate change. forest degradation is a more complex problem than deforestation because it occurs in scattered patterns across large areas of land and is more difficult to assess reliably. this material is from the global forest observation initiative, methods and guidance documentation.
the challenges in monitoring forest degradation on the next screen, you will find a video with an explanation from dr. eric bullock about the challenges in monitoring forest degradation.
explanation video dr. eric bullock from boston university video duration: 5’ 41”

technical challenges for mapping and monitoring forest degradation cloud coverage humid tropical forests are frequently covered by cloud cover spatial scale degradation events can often occur at a smaller spatial scale than freely available remote sensing data single-date imagery affected by clouds, shadow, and other noise temporal considerations degradation events can often be visible from above for a short period of time and need repeated observations historical context is needed to determine undisturbed forest “baseline”

individual pixels can be clear even if clouds in image extract change information based on temporal trajectory at pixel level analysis based on rich time series can be powerful tool for monitoring degradation below: swir1 time series for one landsat pixel trajectory in central africa republic pixel-level time series analysis 1 pixel in image

plethora of new approaches that make use of very dense time series pixel-level analysis of landsat, modis, and sentinel 1 and 2 landsat especially well suited open data archive high (30 m2) spatial resolution surface reflectance sensitive to forest/non-forest land covers change detected using statistical methods to structural break detection characterize trends through time robust to clouds and other noise temporally-consistent land-cover labels coded and remote sensing kennedy et al., 2010 cohen et al., 2017

continuous change detection and classification (ccdc; zhu and woodcock, 2014) time series approach to land change monitoring using landsat usgs lcmap program surface reflectance data not specific to any type of change continuous degradation detection algorithm lcmap products created with ccdcsource: michelle bouchard, usgs zhu and woodcock, 2014

single-date classification approach to mapping degradation and deforestation estimation of sub-pixel forest parameters using spectral mixture analysis anniversary imagery subject to issues mentioned previously decision tree parameterized for dense evergreen forests and therefore not applicable to seasonal forests application over large areas remains a challenge souza et al., 2005, 2013 souza et al., 2005

implementation on google earth engine to easily operate over large areas pixel-trajectory analysis of sub-pixel forest composition parameters structural break detection based on time series applicable in sample-based frameworks for estimating area and accuracy coded and degradation research bullock et al., 2020b bullock et al., 2020a image processing approach in souza et al, (2005) sensitive to degradation with the time series approach to change detection in ccdc applied on google earth engine – for large area analysis
how coded works on the next screen, you will find a video from dr. eric bullock describing how coded works.
explanation video dr. eric bullock from boston university video duration: 17’ 05”
self assessment click next to continue. copyright © 2020

incorrect forest degradation often does not result in a permanent change to the canopy and may be visible from satellites for under a year. forest degradation is the second ‘d’ in redd (reduced emissions from deforestation and degradation). the opening of the landsat archive was instrumental to forest monitoring, but global degradation mapping from causes such as selective logging and fire has yet to be achieved. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct the damage from forest degradation can be minimal, resulting in canopy gaps that are not permanent. continue continue continue continue continue continue self assessment question 1 of 4: which of the following are true statements about forest degradation? a) forest degradation, by definition, results in a permanent change to the forest canopy. a) forest degradation, by definition, results in a permanent change to the forest canopy. a) forest degradation, by definition, results in a permanent change to the forest canopy. a) forest degradation, by definition, results in a permanent change to the forest canopy. a) forest degradation, by definition, results in a permanent change to the forest canopy. a) forest degradation, by definition, results in a permanent change to the forest canopy. b) forest degradation is not part of the original un-redd framework. b) forest degradation is not part of the original un-redd framework. b) forest degradation is not part of the original un-redd framework. b) forest degradation is not part of the original un-redd framework. b) forest degradation is not part of the original un-redd framework. b) forest degradation is not part of the original un-redd framework. c) the damage from forest degradation can be minimal, resulting in canopy gaps that are not permanent. c) the damage from forest degradation can be minimal, resulting in canopy gaps that are not permanent. c) the damage from forest degradation can be minimal, resulting in canopy gaps that are not permanent. c) the damage from forest degradation can be minimal, resulting in canopy gaps that are not permanent. c) the damage from forest degradation can be minimal, resulting in canopy gaps that are not permanent. c) the damage from forest degradation can be minimal, resulting in canopy gaps that are not permanent. d) global mapping of forest degradation was achieved immediately following the opening of the landsat archive. d) global mapping of forest degradation was achieved immediately following the opening of the landsat archive. d) global mapping of forest degradation was achieved immediately following the opening of the landsat archive. d) global mapping of forest degradation was achieved immediately following the opening of the landsat archive. d) global mapping of forest degradation was achieved immediately following the opening of the landsat archive. d) global mapping of forest degradation was achieved immediately following the opening of the landsat archive.

incorrect the spatial scale of degradation relative to the resolution of the imagery used in the analysis can cause its signal in the data to be minimal, however, this is not the only correct answer. regeneration can cause visible damage from the degradation event to be temporary, however, this is not the only correct answer. noise due to clouds and cloud shadows can contaminate data and make automated classification challenging, however, this is not the only answer. all of these factors are important considerations that can cause challenges when mapping degradation. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct all of these factors are important considerations that can cause challenges when mapping degradation. continue continue continue continue continue continue self assessment question 2 of 4: which of the following is an important consideration when mapping degradation: a) spatial scale a) spatial scale a) spatial scale a) spatial scale a) spatial scale a) spatial scale b) length of the time damage from the event is visible to satellites b) length of the time damage from the event is visible to satellites b) length of the time damage from the event is visible to satellites b) length of the time damage from the event is visible to satellites b) length of the time damage from the event is visible to satellites b) length of the time damage from the event is visible to satellites c) inherent noise in the remotely sensed imagery c) inherent noise in the remotely sensed imagery c) inherent noise in the remotely sensed imagery c) inherent noise in the remotely sensed imagery c) inherent noise in the remotely sensed imagery c) inherent noise in the remotely sensed imagery d) all of the above d) all of the above d) all of the above d) all of the above d) all of the above d) all of the above

incorrect the acronym ndfi stands for: normalized difference fraction index continue continue continue continue continue continue correct the acronym ndfi stands for: normalized difference fraction index continue continue continue continue continue continue self assessment question 3 of 4: what does the acronym ndfi stand for? a) normalized difference fraction index a) normalized difference fraction index a) normalized difference fraction index a) normalized difference fraction index a) normalized difference fraction index a) normalized difference fraction index b) normalized degradation forest index b) normalized degradation forest index b) normalized degradation forest index b) normalized degradation forest index b) normalized degradation forest index b) normalized degradation forest index c) negative degradation in forest investments c) negative degradation in forest investments c) negative degradation in forest investments c) negative degradation in forest investments c) negative degradation in forest investments c) negative degradation in forest investments d) nested decoupling of forest indices d) nested decoupling of forest indices d) nested decoupling of forest indices d) nested decoupling of forest indices d) nested decoupling of forest indices d) nested decoupling of forest indices

incorrect spectral mixture analysis and calculation of ndfi is an image-processing technique that is part of coded. coded operates at the pixel scale, and therefore only removes individual pixels flagged as a cloud. classification is performed on regression model parameters and is continuous through time. coded uses the landsat surface reflectance products. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct spectral mixture analysis and calculation of ndfi is an image-processing technique that is part of coded. continue continue continue continue continue continue self assessment question 4 of 4: which image-processing technique is part of coded? a) filtering for images with under 10% clouds for the entire scene a) filtering for images with under 10% clouds for the entire scene a) filtering for images with under 10% clouds for the entire scene a) filtering for images with under 10% clouds for the entire scene a) filtering for images with under 10% clouds for the entire scene a) filtering for images with under 10% clouds for the entire scene b) post-classification map comparison b) post-classification map comparison b) post-classification map comparison b) post-classification map comparison b) post-classification map comparison b) post-classification map comparison c) spectral mixture analysis and calculation of ndfi c) spectral mixture analysis and calculation of ndfi c) spectral mixture analysis and calculation of ndfi c) spectral mixture analysis and calculation of ndfi c) spectral mixture analysis and calculation of ndfi c) spectral mixture analysis and calculation of ndfi d) dark-object subtraction for atmospheric correction d) dark-object subtraction for atmospheric correction d) dark-object subtraction for atmospheric correction d) dark-object subtraction for atmospheric correction d) dark-object subtraction for atmospheric correction d) dark-object subtraction for atmospheric correction

how to create a change map using coded. running coded interactive graphical user interface (gui) available in english, french, and spanish built on javascript api output layers change date change magnitude change type coded documentation

considerations for running coded coded was developed in the amazon using forest spectral parameters optimized for the region, and may not be applicable everywhere remember, forest degradation mapping is challenging. be prepared to perform tests and modify parameters coded is offered for free on google earth engine and is maintained by eric bullock, so please be patient with inquiries it is likely that there are better approaches to monitoring forest degradation, especially in temperate climates. results obtained using coded are likely to contain errors, and it is the user’s responsibility to properly accommodate them
demonstration of coded on the next screen, you will find a video with a demonstration of coded by dr. eric bullock

explanation video – demonstration of coded dr. eric bullock from boston university guide book guide book guide book guide book guide book guide book video duration: 36’ 43” important: use the script from the gee repository.

summary degradation mapping is achievable over large areas many of the traditional challenges in mapping forest degradation can be addressed using techniques for time series analysis continuous degradation detection (coded) was designed to address common challenges in mapping forest degradation coded is open access on google earth engine
